title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and efficiency. Eligible projects aim to mitigate traffic congestion, reduce emissions, save energy, and enhance railroad operations. Eligible projects under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving rail-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and maintaining track structures. Funding is not provided for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or passenger facilities. Projects must be included in long-range transportation plans or state transportation improvement programs to be funded. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. At least 20 percent of project costs must be covered by non-Federal public sources. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation will allocate 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and grade crossings. The remaining 20% will be used for national projects with significant public benefit. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation must ensure that workers on projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. At least 10% of funds must go to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. The term "rail miles" refers to route miles, not track miles, and "railroad" includes freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. A separate 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on such equipment within 6 months of it being placed in service, unless it is a replacement part or accessory. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of being placed in service, except for replacement parts or accessories. Installers are secondarily liable for the tax. The amendments made by this section regarding the tax on rail transportation of persons or property will take effect on October 1, 2003. A tax is imposed on taxable rail transportation of persons, with rates of 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases, to be paid by the person making the payment. "SEC. 4242. TRANSPORTATION OF PROPERTY." A 1% tax is imposed on amounts paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except in cases where payments are made outside the United States, in which the tax is to be paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the entity providing the last segment of the transportation. The 1% tax is imposed on payments for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. For taxable rail transportation within the United States, excluding mass transit, the tax applies to payments made for transportation services, including layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply for payments made outside the US and tax deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. The tax imposed on rail transportation in the US includes deductions on refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment. Carriers must report any uncollected tax to the Secretary. If the tax is not paid at the time of transportation payment, the carrier providing the initial segment must pay the tax. The amendments made by this section regarding the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund will take effect on October 1, 2003. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by various sources including taxes on railroad locomotives, customs duties, fuel taxes, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The funds are to be used for expenditures related to carrying out title I. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund receives funding from various sources, including royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. These funds are used for expenditures related to carrying out title I of the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund, funded by royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands, supports expenditures for the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
